name: Saraswati Puja & Havan
description: Saraswati is the goddess of learning and the arts. Invoking her grace is important prior to the commencement of education and the undertaking of a new art form. The pujas is done for children prior to their first day of school or university, or on Vijayadashami/Dussehra day

name: Ayushya Havan
description: This lesser known yet impactful Vedic Birthday ceremony invokes blessings for a healthy and prosperous year ahead.

name: Grhapravesham
description: Traditionally performed the day of moving in, this ceremony seeks to purify and establish stability and growth in oneâ€™s living space.

name: Sudarshana Puja & Havan
description: Narasimha is the fourth incarnation of Vishnu and the protector of His devotees. Along with Sudarshana, the divine discus of Vishnu, He is invoked to remove any negative forces, evil eye or influence of invisible entities or curses.

name: Aikyamatya Suktam Havan
description: This ceremony is one the most ancient ways to celebrate marriage anniversaries and invoke harmony and love in relationships. Mantras from the last part of the Rg Veda are chanted and offerings are made asking for unity in mind and heart.

name: Ganapati Puja & Havan
description: Ganesha is known as the remover of all obstacles. Often done at the beginning of new ventures or prior to the start of any major life event, this puja is done to clear any internal and external roadblocks to success.

name: Navagraha Puja & Havan
description: The Nava-grahas are the nine celestial planets in Vedic Astrology that govern various aspects of our personality and karma. Commonly done as a pre-wedding ceremony, this puja invokes the benevolent aspects of the grahas to re-establish alignment in oneself.

name: Dhanvantari Puja & Havan
description: Dhanvantari is the divine physician from whom we received the science of Ayurveda. This ceremony invokes His grace to relieve one from any health-related issues and prepare for any future treatments/procedures to be undergone.

name: Satyanarayana Katha
description: During this puja, the pastimes of Lord Vishnu and his devotees are heard and reflected upon. The glory of this puja is given in detail in the Skanda Purana, which states that the recitation of these pastimes with full faith fulfils all desires in the world here and hereafter. This puja is usually performed on a full moon day (Purnima), but can be done any other time as well.
